title: Wait, did Google just announce an 'Apple Arcade' killer?
text:
CLOSE USA TODAY consumer editor Michelle Maltais and Common Sense Media executive editor Sierra Filucci share ways to manage your household’s attachment to media and electronic devices. USA TODAY

Video gamers might be buzzing about Apple Arcade – a just-launched gaming subscription service from the world’s biggest tech company – but many might’ve missed Google’s announcement last week, tied to its own service, Google Play Pass.

Wait, what?

Don’t worry, we can bring you up to speed.

Both affordable subscription services offer a ton of content to play around with, without ads or in-app purchases, that can be accessed on several devices.

Similar approach, sure, and Google’s timing – immediately following Apple’s launch – isn’t likely a coincidence, but there are some differences between Google Play Pass and Apple Arcade.

Here’s a comparative look at the two platforms.

Apple’s new gaming service enjoys an easy-to-navigate interface – to help find the right titles for you and your family. (Photo: Apple)

Platforms, cost

For $4.99/month after a 30-day free trial, Apple Arcade boasts 100+ new and exclusive games within its launch window (currently, there are more than 70 games, with an additional 30 rolling out over new few weeks, says Apple). By “exclusive,” Apple says these games cannot be found on any other mobile platform, but a few might have a console or PC version. With a wide selection of genres to choose from, Apple Arcade titles are playable on iPhone, iPod touch, iPad, and Apple TV, and with Mac coming next month. Families of up to five people can share an account. The interface is easy to navigate through, allowing you to see profiled games, browse by genre, search, read reviews, and more.

Apple Arcade: This is what will make the subscription service a winner

Game over? Video game retailer GameStop closing 180 to 200 stores globally

Google Play Pass also costs $4.99/month after a 10-day free trial, but there’s currently a promotion that offers the service for $1.99/month for the first year – so long as you sign up on or before Oct. 10.

Google Play Pass offers more than 350 games and app for a low monthly subscription cost. (Photo: Google)

According to Google, there are more than 350 games and apps available through the service. Like Apple, the selection will be refreshed on a regular basis, to keep things fresh. Games make up more than two-thirds of the content, but unlike Apple, the games consist of previously released titles and might be available on other mobile (or other) platforms.

Google Play Pass works with Android phones, tablets and Chromebooks (running Android 4.4 or later). The account can be shared with up to five other family members (totaling six members, in total).

Selection of games

Apple Arcade has a slew of impressive launch titles ranging from arcade fun ("Frogger in Toy Town"), puzzle games ("Where Cards Fall"), and story-based action ("The Pathless") to adventure titles ("Beyond a Steel Sky"), sports ("Skate City") and role-playing games (like "Oceanhorn 2: Knights of the Lost Realm").

There really is something for everyone, here, including kids ("LEGO Brawls"), tweens ("Projection: First Light"), teens ("Hot Lava") and adults ("Bleak Sword").

Start playing on one device, pick up on another, play online or off, and these games work with Screen Time and parental controls.

While not new or exclusive, Google has curated a collection of great games across several genres, including the likes of "Monument Valley," "Terraria," Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic," "Risk," "LIMBO," "Mini Metro," and "Old Man’s Journey," to name a few.

Like Apple, there’s a strong value proposition, especially considering some games may cost as much as $7.99 on its own (like "Stardew Valley"), which is included here as part of the one low price per month. Coming next month are games like "This War of Mine," a war-based survival thriller, and "Cytus," a rhythm game.

All games work with parental controls, so parents can decide what tiles they allow the kids to play.

For both services, it should be noted you don’t own the games – it’s more of a rental model – so you can’t go back to your saved game if you stop paying for the service.

Several Apple devices work with Apple Arcade, including Macs next month. (Photo: Apple)

Summary

Unless you use devices that run both Apple and Android (usually it’s either-or), these two services aren’t really in competition with one another. That is, Google Play Pass won’t appeal to someone on an iPhone, iPad, Apple TV or Mac as it’s simply not supported by that hardware. Same goes for those who use an Android phone or tablet, or Chromebook, because Apple Arcade won’t work with those devices.

Even if you do own both Apple and Android-based machines, there are differences here. Subjectively speaking, Apple has better-quality games, they’re newer, and you won’t find them on other mobile devices. These can be played on a TV, too, if you own Apple TV.

But Google trumps Apple in quantity (more than 250 games opposed to 70 right now) and bests Apple in price (temporarily $1.99/month for the first year compared to Apple’s $4.99/month). Plus, Google Play Pass also includes many ad-free apps tied to productivity, fitness, stargazing, and many others -- if that’s of interest to you.

Because of the relatively low cost and (mostly) high caliber of games, you really can’t go wrong with either Apple Arcade or Google Play Pass. It’s a win for gamers on the go, across the board.
